column6: (Korman & Schick 2021): Cheakamus Project Water Use Plan Project: Synthesis of Adult and Juvenile Steelhead Data to Evaluate Effects of the WUP Flow Regime in the Cheakamus River
column7:
Josh Korman and Jody Schick
Ecometric Research
3560 W 22nd Ave.
Vancouver, BC
V6S 1J3
column10: egg deposition based on female spawner sizes, est. fecundity, and sex ratio; also egg deposition of resident rainbow trout. Estimates of spawning stock that determine subsequent recruitment can be improved by accounting for inter annual variation in sex ratios and fecundity of spawners. To evaluate these factors for Cheakamus Steelhead, we computed egg deposition in years when information on sex ratio and female fork length were available from angling surveys. Annual egg deposition was computed as the product of total escapement, the proportion of the escapement made up of females, and fecundity.

column6: (Korman & Schick 2021): Cheakamus Project Water Use Plan Project: Synthesis of Adult and Juvenile Steelhead Data to Evaluate Effects of the WUP Flow Regime in the Cheakamus River
column7:
Josh Korman and Jody Schick
Ecometric Research
3560 W 22nd Ave.
Vancouver, BC
V6S 1J4
column10: Steelhead escapement to the Cheakamus River is estimated by a model which integrates data on raw counts from swim surveys, run-timing determined from radio telemetry, and mark-recapture to determine observer efficiency during swims (Korman et al. 2007, Korman and Schick 2017, Fig. 3.1). The area surveyed for returning Steelhead is limited to the upper 14.5 km of the anadromous portion of the river, and begins approximately 500 m below a natural barrier, extending to the confluence with the Cheekye River (Fig. 1.1). On each survey, a team of three divers floats the entire survey area and record the number of Steelhead, resident rainbow trout, and bull trout that are observed. These surveys have been conducted over 24 years between 1996 and 2020 (no surveys were conducted in 1997 due to disputes around the IFA).

column6: (Korman & Schick 2021): Cheakamus Project Water Use Plan Project: Synthesis of Adult and Juvenile Steelhead Data to Evaluate Effects of the WUP Flow Regime in the Cheakamus River
column7:
Josh Korman and Jody Schick
Ecometric Research
3560 W 22nd Ave.
Vancouver, BC
V6S 1J5
column10:
The abundance of juvenile steelhead in the fall and spring is estimated by a combination of electrofishing and snorkel surveys (Korman et al. 2012). We used a multi-gear two-phase sampling design to estimate the abundance of age 0+-, 1+-, and 2+ juvenile steelhead in the Cheakamus and Brohm Rivers. Data from Brohm River provides a reference or control system to compare with results from the Cheakamus, which is influenced by flow regulation.

The abundance of Steelhead, Chinook, and coho smolts, as well as the abundance of Chinook, Pink, and Chum fry, are estimated using data from two Rotary Screw Traps (RST) located at river KM 5.5 adjacent to the North Vancouver Outdoor School (Melville et al. 2012, Fig. 1.1).
